awd_titl_txt: Stress Formation and Relaxation in colloidal Dispersions: Transient, Nonlinear Microrheology
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Zia, Roseanna
Proposal Number: 1605836

The goal of the proposed research is to investigate colloidal dispersions when forces and stresses acting on them change. Both theoretical analysis and a class of computations known as Accelerated Stokesian Dynamics simulations will be used to accomplish this goal. The work could have an impact on the chemical and food industry, where control of material properties and of complex fluids, like colloids, is important.

The goal of the proposed research is to develop predictive theory and computational models for the temporal formation and relaxation of viscosity and stress in colloidal dispersions via the framework of active microrheology, with a focus on connections to particle microstructure as it evolves in time. Most non-equilibrium microrheological work to date has focused on steady-state flow behavior, yielding insight into steady-state non-Newtonian behaviors, relating them to flow-strength induced changes in the relative contributions of hydrodynamic, Brownian, and interparticle forces. However, understanding of how such relative contributions evolve in time-during flow startup and cessation-lags behind. Such understanding is key to resolving important questions such as the origins of stress "overshoots" during flow startup, and whether structural evolution and rheological evolution reach steady state simultaneously. The results of the proposed research are of fundamental scientific interest and will impact applications as diverse as intracellular flow, drilling fluids, and impact-resistant materials. The PI hypothesizes that the relative contributions of hydrodynamic, interparticle, and Brownian forces to the stress and viscosity in colloidal dispersions are not instantaneously formed upon flow startup, and thus that the climb to steady state rheology may lead or lag formation of steady state structure. The proposed work will combine theoretical and computational rheological studies. Theoretical studies will center on formulation and solution of time-dependent Smoluchowski equations, which will then be utilized to compute suspension viscosity and stress as it evolves in time, for any range of interparticle repulsion (i.e., strength of hydrodynamic interactions), particle size ratio, and attractive potentials. The educational plan will improve the participation of underrepresented students via mentored learning utilizing guided, hands-on experiments. The PI will develop fluid mechanics modules for classrooms and outreach at Cornell University, rheology conferences, and quarterly "Science Days" at National Academy Foundation high schools for underrepresented minority students.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Complex fluids are everywhere in science and nature: over 90% of biological fluids, most pharmaceutical fluids, many foods, and industrial coatings and fertilizers are just a few examples.  Complex fluids differ from simple fluids in content and this changes their behavior. Complex fluids are microscopically small particles suspended in a fluid – such as a suspension (like paint or cough syrup), a foam (such as shave cream), or an emulsion (such as salad dressing or ice cream).  The particles can be well-defined and compact like a small sphere, or long and wiggly like polymer strands that can get entangled, or somewhere in between.  The key feature is that the suspended particles are “large” compared to the molecules of the fluid they are suspended in, so when the whole material flows, the particles cannot quite follow the streamlines of the flow. This changes their arrangement in the fluid, and they then interact, making the flow more difficult – producing higher viscosity, for example. These interactions can produce flow thickening (cornstarch monsters or bullet-proof vests) or memory effects similar to a rubber band springing back after being stretched (shampoo retracting back into the nozzle after pouring is stopped). This time-dependent behavior is critical to the processing and use of complex fluids, and in fact underlies the effectiveness of how mucus in the lungs allows us to breathe and clear infections. But the macroscopic behavior is controlled at the microscopic level by microscopic forces between the particles. Detailed understanding of the interplay between microscopic forces in suspensions, and how their relative strengths change with flow, is an important element in forming structure–property relationships required for predictive theory and materials design, for both steady-state and transient flow conditions. Sustained, flow-dependent microstructural asymmetry underlies non-Newtonian steady-state rheology in Brownian suspensions, and can be traced to the duration and trajectories of pair-level particle encounters, which are in turn shaped by the relative dominance of hydrodynamic and non-hydrodynamic microscopic forces. Each of these forces produces colloidal motion over a distinct time scale: if the speed of Brownian motion is high compared to advection (or particles are rough), a relative Stokes flow trajectory will be overlaid with many random displacements before the encounter is complete. A continuous competition between building and relaxing structure thus sustains non-Newtonian rheology. An understanding of the time scales over which various microscopic forces – hydrodynamic, Brownian and interparticle – distort and relax structure is important in particle formulations to give desired material responsiveness. It is also of broader heuristic value, e.g. in understanding how biological systems change surface properties to modulate the media in which they operate. While much robust theory exists for steady-state flow, far less study has been devoted to the study of transient rheology and is relevant to intermittent flow ranging from shaving cream dispersions to migration of nuclei during biological cell division. 

Intellectual Merit:

Transient flows in colloidal suspensions can be exploited to reveal the disparity in timescales over which microscopic transport processes sustain and dissipate microstructural distortions associated with macroscopic suspension rheology.  Prior studies of rheological behavior of colloids during flow startup have revealed interesting parallels to steady-state non- Newtonian rheology, but thus far have provided little quantitative microstructural support. Stress or viscosity “overshoots” during the transition to steady, long-time flow have been observed in sheared colloidal dispersions, startup microrheological flow,sheared colloidal glasses, and gels, leading to hypotheses that pronounced structural rearrangement occurs at the peak stress, such as detachment of clusters of particles from a network, disintegration of clusters, and rupture of network strands. Examination of the contributions to stress arising from Brownian and hydrodynamic forces confirmed prior hypothees that attributed the rate of initial growth to nonequilibrium hydrodynamic and Brownian forces, but did not explain the overshoot. In this work, we explore the connections between transient evolution of rheological behavior and microscopic rate processes of a semidilute colloidal dispersion during flow startup and cessation. Overall, the structural and rheological evolution with time at a fixed value of Pe reveals a time-evolving balance between microscopic forces, mimicking the development of the steady- state balance with increasing Pe.

Broader Impacts:

Microrheology provides a tool for interrogating very small-scale systems such as the interior of biological cells, which are too small for conventional tools to reach. Our work contributes a substantial missing piece to the overall body of work aimed at enabling interrogation of biological cells: the ability to predict and interpret how the initiation and cessation of biomolecule motion can indicate changing viscosity of cytoplasm, and how the cell changes the strength of hydrodynamic interactions between biomolecules to affect this coupling.
